question: Managing the Fhrer's security must be quite an undertaking.
answer: Irregularity is the Fhrer's precaution of choice.

question: I can assure you he's safe here. Relax, Brandt. Enjoy your meal. I understand you're returning to Berlin this afternoon... Could I trouble you to deliver a package to Colonel Stieff? With my regards to Colonel Stieff.
answer: Cointreau? You better hope I don't get thirsty on the flight.

question: He's... landed. Get me Colonel Brandt... Colonel? Tresckow... I trust you landed safely... I hate to trouble you but there's been a bit of a mix up. It seems you have the wrong bottles for Colonel Stieff. You... do still have the package? I can be at your office first thing tomorrow morning to pick it up. Terribly sorry for the inconvenience... Thank you. There's only one way to be sure... I can only guess the altitude caused the fuse to malfunction. First the beer hall, Memorial Day - now this. Someone is watching over that sonofabitch, I swear it.
answer: We've been discovered.

question: What makes you think-
answer: Oster's been arrested. The Gestapo came for him last night. Did you hear what I said?

question: The Gestapo could have arrested him for anything. Find a replacement.
answer: There's no one we can trust. Not in Berlin.

question: Then stop looking in Berlin.
answer: You'll forgive me, General. This little round-up has had me writing reports all day. Dissenters. A plot against the Fhrer. You'd be surprised, the number of cowards in this army that would be willing to stand against the Reich. Of course. It's one thing to think you know what's right. What matters is having the strength to do it. Is this what you've come for? Perhaps we should open it.

question: I beg your pardon.
answer: You've come a long way. You must be thirsty.

question: I wonder how the Fhrer, who does not partake, would feel about an officer who did so on duty... Colonel Brandt.
answer: I took you for another sort, General.

question: Mrs. Stauffenberg?
answer: The Colonel's brother, Berthold.

question: Perhaps before you see the Colonel we should go to my office and-
answer: I will see my husband now.

question: He's been constant with fever but he refuses any pain killers. The right hand has been amputated above the wrist. He's lost the fourth and fifth fingers on the left. We... couldn't save the left eye.
answer: His ring.

question: I don't-
answer: He had a ring on his right hand. Where is it?

question: I'm sorry... His hand was amputated in the field... I'm afraid-
answer: Thank you.

question: I don't know what I ever did with ten. I'm wanted in Berlin. Are you asking as a member of the High Command? You can speak openly, General. He died just before you came in.
answer: We could use your help.

question: I'm a field officer.
answer: This war can't be won in the field.

question: That's unfortunate for me.
answer: You can't honestly believe you'll make a difference on the front-

question: I'm a soldier, General. I serve my country.
answer: It makes no sense. You opposed Hitler, you opposed the war.

question: The people chose otherwise and here we are. Now we have to win. You know what will happen if we don't.
answer: If we win, it will still be Hitler's Germany.

question: We all took an oath, General.
answer: On behalf of the Fhrer.

question: I'm a twin, you know.
answer: I... I didn't.

question: My brother died the day after we were born.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: He's a man like any other. Flesh and blood. Take him head on and-
answer: I'll say this for you, Doctor... You're certainly delusional enough to take Hitler's place.

question: When that day comes, I'll be sure to remember you.
answer: I doubt you'll remember much of anything.

question: I haven't welcomed him. Not yet. Where does he stand?
answer: For God's sake-

question: He's a field officer. He knows the army better than any of us. I want to hear his opinion.
answer: All right. What do you think, Colonel? Confront Hitler, force him to resign? Or the central solution?

question: You said yourself, I'm a field officer. You all may understand government, but I know the men. A great many of them may hate Hitler, but they all fear him - they fear Himmler, Goebbels, the whole of the Reich. That kind of fear won't just die with Hitler. And as for respect What are you doing here? I thought I left you in Bamberg. It's a wonderful surprise. Thank you, brother.
answer: What do you mean you quit?

question: I came to join the Resistance, not some sewing circle of discarded generals and politicians.
answer: Beck is a just and capable man. As for Goerdeler, well, he's popular. He'll make a good Chancellor.

question: Like Hitler before him, yes? Lately I have to wonder if Germany is even fit to choose her own destiny.
answer: You can't blame the people for this. You have to see the beginning of something to know how it'll end. It's no different than a farmer watching the corn grow. One day it's over his head.

question: Plenty of people thought-
answer: The greatest offenders are not the ones who thought better but the ones who sensed better.

question: What are you trying to say?
answer: I seem to remember you telling me about reports from the Ukraine - the SS forcing Jews to dig their own graves. You said then that Hitler should be removed. An officer's duty, you said. What's changed?

question: I said senior officers. The only men that can get to him.
answer: Perhaps it doesn't matter that you succeed. Perhaps it only matters that you try. Don't you see? Someone has to stand up and show the world that not all of us were like him.

question: Even if they could remove Hitler, they can't hope to seize power. For God's sake, they have no plan.
answer: Then give them one. Find a way. Evil happens when good men do nothing.

question: Hitler's own Reserve Army, using Hitler's own plan and under our command, would automatically seize power in Berlin...
answer: While we put a new government in place.

question: Precisely. It will seem as though we're fighting for Hitler Government, not against it.
answer: But only if Hitler's dead. That is what you're saying, isn't it? The central solution. How else will you make people believe the SS is trying to seize power?

question: I'm afraid it's the only way.
answer: I'm disappointed in you, Colonel. I thought a man of your background would appreciate a more-

question: I'm a soldier first, an aristocrat second.
answer: Yes, but-

question: Ah yes - the hero from Africa. I'd offer my hand but you might not give it back.
answer: I'd say the General's lost more important things this morning.

question: About time they put a man with balls in this office. Have a seat. You too, if you must. They tell me you're critical of the war, Colonel. Not that you don't seem to have good reason.
answer: I am critical of losing the war, General. All wars - as in Africa - are lost through indecision.

question: In the field, you mean.
answer: In Berlin.

question: I take it that's why you're here. To make decisions.
answer: I've made my decision, General. I`m here to help others make theirs.

question: They say when there's no clear option, one should do nothing.
answer: We're at war. We must act. Sometimes... rashly.

question: Just what sort of rash action did you have in mind, Colonel?
answer: That would be a decision for the Supreme Military Commander.

question: Supreme Commander, you say.
answer: Second only to the Chancellor.

question: Dammit, Stauffenberg. You scared me half to death.
answer: We'll be closer than that before we're finished.

question: Looking this over, I'm not satisfied that the Reserve Army is enough to shut down Berlin completely.
answer: Yes, I've been giving that some thought. We should include any field units that are home on leave. I've also drawn up an outline for orders to streamline combat groups in order to quietly concentrate forces at vital points - state and government buildings, of course, but also the radio and newspapers. Combat groups will be reorganized as reinforced grenadier regiments. One or two of them can be quickly mobilized, eliminating the usual six hour lag. We blitz the government quarter, arrest all Ministers and Party leaders, surround all SS and police barracks. Any officers who resist will be arrested... or shot. If anyone comes to you, play ignorant. Just tell them-

question: To Operation Valkyrie. I've been transferred to the front.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: Would you have stayed?
answer: Do you think Fromm reported us?

question: It's more likely just... an unfortunate coincidence. Anyway it doesn't matter. You wrote the orders. You know them better than anyone.
answer: You don't mean to say-

question: I'm appointing you military leader of the Resistance. Beck agrees.
answer: But Olbricht-

question: We both know Olbricht hasn't the wit or the spine. No. It's you. One more thing. You were right what you said that first night. It's not enough to kill Hitler. We need to isolate his chain of command. The slightest confusion could crush us. We need to be certain that no conflicting orders get out after the flash.
answer: That greatly limits our options of where and when to make our move, but it's the only way.

question: How will you do it?
answer: Perhaps it's better I don't say.

question: You realize how close I am to Hitler. With one word I could have the Gestapo make you disappear.
answer: Why haven't you then? None of my associates know we've been talking if that's what you're afraid of.

question: But you know. And when the SS catch you, they'll pull you apart like warm bread. It'll be a crime just to have known you then. I warn you. If it means protecting myself, I will expose you. Do not try to contact me again.
answer: You can't report me. Maybe if you had when I first approached you, you'd have been keeping your oath. But now you're just as guilty as-

question: So you think that makes me a sympathizer, eh? You give a man the choice of betraying a fellow officer or his Fhrer and assume his actions will show you his heart. It's not that simple.
answer: It is to me.

question: For the last time, don't push me to make a decision.
answer: I have no choice. It's clear now that without you we have no hope of success. You want us to succeed. Don't you?

question: And what if you do, eh? What then? Will you be any different from Hitler? What of his Reich, his people, the very momentum of history? Will all of that let you be something he isn't?
answer: No.

question: There it is.
answer: But my pregnant wife, our four children, the Germany I first swore to defend... They demand that I be something different. They demand that I fight for their future even if it means... Even if it means that I never see them again. Action is inevitable. As are the consequences. When they come for me I'll do what I can to hide what you knew and when you knew it. But don't delude yourself. You were involved in a crime against your country long before you met me. There's still time to redeem yourself. Only God can judge you now. Leave us, please.

question: But my pregnant wife, our four children, the Germany I first swore to defend... They demand that I be something different. They demand that I fight for their future even if it means... Even if it means that I never see them again. Action is inevitable. As are the consequences. When they come for me I'll do what I can to hide what you knew and when you knew it. But don't delude yourself. You were involved in a crime against your country long before you met me. There's still time to redeem yourself. Only God can judge you now. Leave us, please.
answer: You play the part of bureaucrat beautifully.

question: It's the only time I can relax.
answer: There's a man here to interview as your adjutant.

question: Adjut- What for?
answer: No one told you? You've been promoted Chief of Staff for the Reserve Army.

question: For Christ's sake. Don't I have enough to do?
answer: Unfortunately, your nocturnal activities don't count as service to the Reich.

question: I'll refuse the promotion.
answer: You'll do no such thing.

question: Dammit, I can't handle the work I already-
answer: This is an opportunity we could never have dreamed of. You're in the inner circle now - with genuine access to Hitler, his advisors, his schedule... We need this.

question: We're not ready. We're moving too fast.
answer: Not half as fast as the Allies. An invasion is coming, Colonel. Any day now. We must act and we must act soon. Tresckow may have left you in charge of the "central solution," but in this world I still outrank you. You will accept the appointment. Is that understood? Now. The new man is waiting outside. He comes highly recommended. He might even be an ideal candidate.

question: For what?
answer: We still need an assassin.

question: Be seated. Do you know how this war will end, Haeften? The portrait will be un- hung... And the man will be hung. Bottom line. I'm engaged in high treason with all means available to me. Can I count you in?
answer: For anything, sir. Anything at all.

question: Anything is a very dangerous word.
answer: Five thousand ships, one-hundred thousand men from the combined Allied forces.

question: What about the Panzer divisions in-
answer: They were never dispatched. Word is Hitler took a sleeping pill. His staff was afraid to wake him.

question: First Africa, now France.
answer: The Russians bearing down from the East.

question: Sometimes I wonder if Hitler's real aim is to leave nothing but scorched earth for all of Europe.
answer: Maybe this is a blessing in disguise. Maybe he'll finally listen to reason - consider a truce while he still can.

question: Mein Fhrer, if I may... The situation in Normandy is-
answer: You're dismissed, Stauffenberg.

question: But-
answer: Send your man home, Fromm. Then bring us some brandy.

question: They're all insane. Every one of them except for Speer, and he's nothing but an architect. Tell Beck we've found our assassin... I'll do it myself.
answer: Out of the question. It won't work. We need you here in Berlin.

question: Who else, then? Who can even get as close? Valkyrie is very clear. Once the order is given, the Reserve Army will automatically seize control of the government with or without me.
answer: Orders are not enough. They need a man to follow. The right man.

question: Olbricht will oversee operations in my absence. I can be back in Berlin three hours after Hitler is-
answer: Three very crucial hours.

question: We both know there's no other way.
answer: I'll tell the others- I'm afraid whatever the outcome, I won't be there to see it.

question: Nonsense. You're stronger than you think. You might just be the strongest one of all.
answer: ...After that I thought I'd take the children to the country for a few days to see my- Claus? Have you heard a word I said?

question: The country... Nina. Listen. I want you to delay your trip. Just for a while.
answer: Does this have something to do with... your work?

question: I would just be more comfortable knowing where you are - until I'm back from Berlin. Things will be different then. I promise.
answer: How long until... until we see you?

question: A few days. If all goes well. Then we can travel as a family.
answer: And if things... don't go well?

question: I love you, Nina.
answer: And I love you... What- Go be with your children.

question: Himmler is expected to be at the meeting as well. Don't proceed unless you can get them both.
answer: That could be difficult.

question: Why kill a madman just to have a lunatic take his place?
answer: This is Goerdeler's idea, isn't it?

question: The members are in total agreement on this.
answer: Fucking politicians. I'll hold off if the decision is unanimous. And I want another man on the committee. A soldier.

question: And just who this soldier be?
answer: Him.

question: Lieutenant.
answer: What about it?

question: This order is calling the Reserve Army for some sort of stand-by action... in Berlin.
answer: Looks like a drill of some kind.

question: Valkyrie? I've never heard of that.
answer: Send the order through, Sergeant.

question: I don't think I am alone when I say your judgement is in question. I would like to take a vote.
answer: Carl. Carl, if I may have a word with you in private.

question: If you have something to say, Ludwig, say it here. Say it now.
answer: Very well. There's no need to vote. I consider you a friend. And I look forward to the day when we can once again live as free men. But you've become a liability. I'm sorry it has to be this way.

question: Wha... What are you saying?
answer: Fellgiebel informed me this evening... Himmler's issued an order for your arrest. You'll have to leave Germany. Tonight. When we've succeeded with the central solution you'll return as Chancellor. Until then-

question: This is your doing, isn't it? ISN'T IT? You can't just get rid of me like this. I am the man Germany will follow. I'm... I... Ludwig, I-
answer: Disappear, Carl. Avoid contact with anyone. No more indecision. From now on, Stauffenberg has discretion.

question: I'll do my job. You just take Berlin. I'd like to place a call to Bamberg, please.
answer: Have you made your peace with God, then?

question: As best I can.
answer: Then you have nothing to fear.

question: I know the soldier inside me is a traitor. I wonder how I'll be judged as a man.
answer: By history?

question: By God.
answer: In the end, we answer only to ourselves. Did you reach your wife?

question: Bombing in Ebingen. I can't get through.
answer: Ebingen is a long way from Bamberg. They're safe. You've seen to that. To think... You came to us a wounded soldier from Africa. Now... Now you are both the architect and the assassin. I'm still trying to understand how this came to be.

question: Like a farmer watching the corn grow. One day it's over his head...
answer: What's that?

question: Nothing...
answer: Gentlemen, may I introduce Chief Helldorf. He's guaranteed the full support of the Berlin Police. We can begin. Hitler has scheduled a military briefing for today at one o'clock. Stauffenberg will strike regardless of who else is present. Once in position, he will signal us once to alert the troops and again after the flash... Assuming Fromm refuses to join us, Olbricht will take Command of the Reserve Army and initiate Operation Valkyrie. Then he'll notify all district commanders between Paris and Berlin that the SS is attempting to seize power. The Reserve Army will arrest all SS, Gestapo and Nazi officials. When the time is right, Witzleben and I will arrive at the War Ministry and assume the roles of Commander of the Armed Forces and Head of State, respectively. With Berlin secured, Goerdeler will return and address the nation as our new Chancellor. Then, God willing, we can negotiate a truce with the Allies and spare Europe from total destruction. Gentlemen, this is the most important day of your lives. Long live sacred Germany.

question: You're arming them... now?
answer: No room for error this time. Assume I have ten minutes in this heat. Two minutes for the walk, one for the security check and one to the bunker. Three minutes for the walk back. That's seven.

question: Leaving just three minutes to place the bomb.
answer: Plenty of time.

question: I have everything I need, Lieutenant. Thank you.
answer: Please. Let me help you with that.

question: I can manage, thank you. Where are they going?
answer: It's too hot. The briefing has been moved to the conference hut. Sir, your briefcase. I insist.

question: I didn't hear you. Come again. Fellgiebel. FELLGIEBEL.
answer: Well, what did he say?

question: I... couldn't be sure. It sounded as though he said... Hitler is still alive.
answer: Get him back on the line.

question: Sir... The bomb did go off. That much was clear. Fellgiebel's next step will be to sever all communications. Colonel Stauffenberg was explicit. We initiate Valkyrie regardless.
answer: Only Fromm can initiate. You know that.

question: Then lie. Tell him Hitler's dead. Or arrest him. But do it now. Sir... Did you hear me? You have to give the order to initiate Valkyrie. This is our only-
answer: I'm not doing anything until I talk to Fellgiebel. Get him back on the phone. NOW.

question: Every second we stand here arguing is a second lost.
answer: I can't initiate Valkyrie without confirmation that Hitler's dead. It's too great a risk.

question: What about Stauffenberg? What about his risk? He did his part and now you're abandoning him.
answer: Watch yourself, Colonel.

question: Shouldn't you be consulting Beck?
answer: I know just what Beck will say. He's a dying man. What does he have to lose?

question: At least put the Reserve Army on alert.
answer: I can't cover up another false alarm. When Stauffenberg returns, when he gives me confirmation. Then we'll proceed.

question: And where are you going?
answer: The same place you are. Lunch.

question: The one-eyed Colonel...
answer: Stauffenberg.

question: He left the building very abruptly - just before the explosion.
answer: Several men left the building before the explosion.

question: Yes, sir. Of course. But...
answer: But what? Spit it out, man.

question: It's been three hours, Olbricht. What the hell have you been doing?
answer: We've had no confirmation that-

question: Dammit man, I saw the explosion myself. Nothing else matters now. We are committed.
answer: Dear God.

question: Now where is Fromm? Is he with us or did you-
answer: I- No one has spoken to him yet.

question: Listen to me, Olbricht. Never mind Germany. Never mind Europe. Your life is at stake now, do you understand? If you want to live through the night you'll do exactly as I say.
answer: I understand.

question: The second you hang up the phone, initiate Operation Valkyrie in Fromm's name. Then go over to his office in force, give him the choice to join us or place him under immediate arrest. Do I make myself perfectly clear?
answer: I understand.

question: I am at the airfield now. I will be in Fromm's office in fifteen minutes. Be there when I arrive.
answer: Get Beck and the others. Tell them it's time. This is General Olbricht calling on behalf of General Fromm - Commander of the Home Army. Adolf Hitler, is dead. A group of radicals from the SS are attempting to seize control of the government. Operation Valkyrie is in effect. All military districts, training schools and replacement troops are to take control of essential government offices at once...

question: Who told you the Fhrer was dead?
answer: General Fellgiebel. At the Wolf's Lair.

question: This is Fromm. Put me through to The Wolf's Lair.
answer: There's no use calling, all communication lines are-

question: Yes. General Fromm for Field Marshal Keitel. Urgent. What's going on up there? The most incredible rumors are circulating in Berlin.
answer: I don't know what you mean. Everything's in order here.

question: There's talk the Fhrer's been assassinated.
answer: Another failed attempt. The Fhrer was never in danger. By the way, where is your man Colonel Stauffenberg?

question: Stauffenberg? On his way back to Berlin, I should think.
answer: Let me know when he arrives. I'd like a word with him.

question: Hitler is dead. Operation Valkyrie is in effect.
answer: OPERATION VAL- WHO GAVE THE ORDER?

question: You did. Be that as it may, the Reserve Army is assuming control here in Berlin. We trust you'll join us.
answer: Dammit, man. Do you realize what you've done? The Fhrer is a-

question: I delivered the bomb myself. I saw the blast. He is dead.
answer: This can't be happening. It's some kind of joke.

question: Are you with us or not?
answer: Colonel, if what you say is true you should shoot yourself at once. The rest of you are under arrest.

question: No, General. You are.
answer: I don't know where you think this is going, but I suggest you men change into civilian clothes and find a place to hide.

question: Lock him upstairs in his private quarters. Make sure his phone lines are cut. You're not in uniform.
answer: This has to be seen as a movement of the people. You're certain he's dead.

question: Helldorf, I'm... glad to see you. We're getting a late start and we need all of the manpower we can muster. Can we count on the police? I can't offer you any guarantees. The decision is yours and yours alone. Can we count on you? Have your men surround the building. No one gets in or out of here without my permission. I want every available soldier on task - we need simultaneous control of every government building in the city. Dismissed.
answer: Acts of vengeance will not be tolerated. We represent a different form of government. We represent what is good and just in Germany.

question: What is it now, Sergeant?
answer: It's just that now we're getting conflicting orders, sir. The Wolf's Lair says one thing, Stauffenberg another.

question: Our job is not to interpret the orders. Our job is to pass them along. Regardless.
answer: Yes, but sir-

question: Very well then... A court martial, convened by me in the Fhrer's absence, has pronounced sentence
answer: The Fhrer will want to put us on trial, make an example of us. This won't win you any favor. And it won't hide you're involvement.

question: Involvement. I don't know what you-
answer: You knew and you did nothing. You're just as guilty as we are. Even more so.

question: Spare me, Stauffenberg.
answer: No one will be spared.
